topic: Why relapse urges come in waves during sobriety

cover.headline: Why relapse urges hit in [waves] during sobriety
cover.subtitle: Your stress and reward circuits rebalance over months, not days.

slides.title: Why urges feel sudden in early sobriety
items: Stress hormones rise, so cravings spike under pressure.
Cue memories fire, making places feel dangerously familiar.
Low dopamine tone leaves reward circuits underpowered between waves.

slides.title: What changes by weeks 2 to 12
items: GABA signaling steadies, which lowers background anxiety surges.
Sleep pressure normalizes, so nighttime urges lose momentum.
Cortisol spikes soften, making stress-triggered cravings shorter.

slides.title: Why waves weaken with longer abstinence
items: Dopamine transport recovers, so baseline motivation slowly returns.
Prefrontal control strengthens, which improves pause-before-react decisions.
Conditioned cues persist, but wave intensity drops with practice.

end.saveLine: Save this if you're scared that craving [waves] mean failure.
end.shareLine: Share with someone who thinks urge [waves] mean they're broken.
end.closer: Each [wave] passed is your brain rewiring.
